message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The intraepidermal accumulation of edematous fluid and widening of intercellular spaces between keratinocytes suggest a diagnosis of eczematous dermatitis. Psoriasis vulgaris is characterized by thick scaly patches, while lichen planus is characterized by purple, flat-topped papules. Acanthosis nigricans has hyperpigmented, thick, velvety plaques most commonly on the neck and axillae.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest eczematous dermatitis, which is characterized by pruritic lesions on the skin. The skin biopsy finding of intraepidermal accumulation of edematous fluid and widening of intercellular spaces between keratinocytes supports this diagnosis. Psoriasis vulgaris is characterized by well-defined red plaques with silvery scales, lichen planus is characterized by pruritic, flat-topped, polygonal papules, and acanthosis nigricans is characterized by velvety, hyperpigmented plaques on the skin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of intraepidermal accumulation of edematous fluid and widening of intercellular spaces between keratinocytes suggests eczematous dermatitis, which is also known for its pruritic rash on the bilateral upper extremities. Psoriasis vulgaris and lichen planus present differently, and acanthosis nigricans is not associated with a rash.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The intraepidermal accumulation of edematous fluid and widening of intercellular spaces between keratinocytes suggest eczematous dermatitis, which is associated with pruritic rashes. Psoriasis vulgaris is characterized by scaly plaques, while lichen planus is characterized by flat-topped papules. Acanthosis nigricans presents as thickened, hyperpigmented skin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The intraepidermal accumulation of edematous fluid and widening of intercellular spaces between keratinocytes suggest eczematous dermatitis. Psoriasis vulgaris is characterized by thick silvery scales, lichen planus by purple, polygonal, planar papules, and acanthosis nigricans by hyperpigmented, velvety plaques.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hallmark of eczematous dermatitis is intraepidermal accumulation of edematous fluid and widening of intercellular spaces between keratinocytes, which is consistent with the skin biopsy findings. Psoriasis vulgaris is characterized by silvery plaques with well-defined borders. Lichen planus presents as itchy, polygonal, flat-topped pink or purple papules. Acanthosis nigricans manifests as dark, velvety thickening of the skin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, eczematous dermatitis is most likely to present with pruritus and the characteristic histological findings of intraepidermal accumulation of edematous fluid and widening intercellular spaces between keratinocytes. Psoriasis vulgaris presents with well-demarcated plaques, lichen planus presents with flat-topped papules, and acanthosis nigricans presents with hyperpigmentation and thickened, velvety plaques.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The intraepidermal accumulation of edematous fluid and widening of intercellular spaces between keratinocytes suggest an eczematous dermatitis, which is the most likely diagnosis. Psoriasis vulgaris and lichen planus both involve hyperkeratosis and acanthosis, but not the intraepidermal accumulation of edematous fluid. Acanthosis nigricans involves hyperpigmented, velvety plaques, typically on the neck, axillae, and groin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of intraepidermal accumulation of edematous fluid and widening of intercellular spaces between keratinocytes are consistent with eczematous dermatitis. Psoriasis vulgaris is characterized by thick, red patches of skin with silvery scales. Lichen planus is characterized by flat-topped, violaceous papules. Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition characterized by hyperpigmented, velvety plaques.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The intraepidermal accumulation of edematous fluid and widening of intercellular spaces between keratinocytes suggest that the most likely diagnosis is eczematous dermatitis. Psoriasis vulgaris is characterized by thick, scaly plaques on the extensor surfaces of the body, lichen planus by shiny, flat-topped, purple papules and plaques, and acanthosis nigricans by thick, velvety hyperpigmentation in intertriginous areas.
